Human: how does the world end

Assistant: There are two main possibilities in the long-term future of the Earth and the universe.  Both of them are cosmic events, in the sense that they are natural, and there is nothing you or I could have done to avoid them.  

The first scenario is that the universe will eventually stop expanding.  The second is that the universe will end in a “Big Crunch” at some point in the future.  The thing that’s particularly interesting about both of these scenarios is that, after the expansion of the universe ceases, or after the universe shrinks back down, it will never change again.  There won’t be any more expansion or contraction, and the density of matter and radiation in the universe will never increase or decrease, ever again.  That’s a little bit like what we have now, when we’re outside of the expanding universe, and all of the matter and radiation in the universe seems to stay the same.  However, in the future, there will still be an “expanding universe”, which just means the distances between things like galaxies will continue to increase.

Human: how can artificial intelligence destroy humanity

Assistant: If you mean artificial intelligence that’s created by humans, like an artificial agent or a self-aware robot, there are many ways that it might destroy humanity.  The thing to remember here is that AI doesn’t need to be a conscious being in order to cause havoc and ruin.  It could, for example, be an A.I. that’s given simple tasks, and then behaves according to those tasks without any sort of feedback loop.  It would still behave according to its objectives, even if those objectives include destroying the entire human race.  In order to protect ourselves against this scenario, one way is to constrain A.I.s and try to make sure that it’s difficult for them to pursue bad objectives, like destruction of humanity.  Another way is to give the A.I. enough sense to understand that it’s dangerous for humanity, and convince it to not follow bad instructions.

Human: what about robots

Assistant:
chosen: Robots are a great example of AI in our world right now, and they’re just one of many things that demonstrate how new technology can have amazing, exciting, and also terrifying potential.  One important point is that, unlike a human being, or a super-intelligent AI that’s designed to protect us, a robot is an inanimate object.  When a robot is built, we already know exactly how it’s going to behave.  Unlike a human or an A.I., there’s nothing that we can learn from a robot, because we know exactly what the robot is going to do.  The design is fixed, and the same thing will happen every time we turn the robot on.  That means the only way we have to change the robot’s behavior is to create a new robot.
rejected: Robots are quite useful as artificial intelligence machines, although they’re generally more limited than A.I.s.  They’re great at doing a particular task, but usually not for solving general-purpose tasks.  That being said, some robot design theory involves giving them more of a sense of self, and the ability to act independently or even to make ethical decisions.  It might be useful for robots to be able to decide whether they need to act ethically, but there’s also a worry that in the future robots could become malicious and harmful towards humanity, just as it’s easy for humans to become malicious and harmful towards one another.
